course.subject: HUMA
course.name: Ethical Theories and Contemporary Issues
course.description: This course introduces students to the ethical theories of deontology (or the ethics of duty), utilitarianism (or the ethics of consequences), and virtue ethics (or the ethics of character). This is followed by an examination of their application to selected contemporary moral issues. In general, issues relating to the following areas may be considered: the environment, business, information technology, and bioethics. The precise issues discussed may vary from year to year.

reviews.author: wtchang
reviews.title: Good Huma course to study
reviews.comment_content:
There are only 3 quizzes and attendance.
It is mainly about different ideas from different philophers.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lesson will be based on discussion. It should be good but to be honest I didn't listen much to it.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is only based on 3 quizzes and attendance. I get above mean for less than or for the first 2 quizzes (I do not know the results of my last quiz) and I get a- finally.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite low. Though there will be readings, I didn't read any of them as I think most of the questions in the quiz will be based on the slides.

reviews.author: Marianne
reviews.comment_content: I am personally very interested in ethics and morality so I rate the content very highly. The first part of the semester you look at three big ethical theories - Virtue Ethics, Deontology, and Utilitarianism. Then you try and apply these different ways of thinking to issues we face in society today ,such as Climate change, animal rights, and poverty. I found the content very relevant and eye-opening.
reviews.comment_teaching: I did like the professor because he never told you how to think, he always presented both sides of an argument and tried to get people to do the same. He also spent a lot of time explaining concepts which i personally enjoyed because sometimes I had no idea what the text meant. However, his powerpoints were just walls of text. They did come in handy though when you needed to revise.
reviews.comment_grading:
I always got a a few marks above the mean and got an A. Was expecting a B after I saw how close to the mean I was but was obviously very happy when I saw my final mark.

There are three quizzes. They are nearly 30% each so kind of feels like a mid term/ final even though he calls it a quiz. I would recommend reading the material to get the best marks but you could probably pretty easily get a B by just studying off the powerpoint.

He takes attendance. Each lesson counts for 1%.
reviews.comment_workload: Incredibly light. The readings are not long at all and for the longer ones he gives you the weekend. If you plan a little bit you wont have any trouble. There is no homework.

reviews.author: NONAMEGUY
reviews.title: Nice Course and you can learn something from it
reviews.comment_content:
The content is not very hard, and gets more and more interested.
1st part: Ethical Theories. Aristotle's Virtue Ethics, Kant's Deontology.

2nd part: Ethical Theories and Contemporary issues. Mill's and Bentham's Utilitarianism. Discussion about crime and punishment, death penalty.

3rd part: Contemporary issues
Euthanasia, hunger and poverty, animal rights and environment.

I think the "contemporary issues" part is quite fun and I'm really intersted in it. It is related to our lives and it makes me think about how I should treat the animals and the environment, which are some topics that I have never thought thoroughly before!! And the theories are the basic theories of the ethics world. It is of no disadvantage knowing more of it as long as you are interested. The theories learnt in the first part will be applied in the 2nd and 3rd part. So I kinda felt like the knowledge is really "applied"haahah.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is a bit boring. The professor is somehow just reading the PPT. If you read the materials, it would be much clearer because he explains the key parts.

The ppt is really ugly cause THERE ARE ONLY WORDS ON IT. And the structure is quite boring. But be careful with the ppt. This semester, there are questions like "what are the 2nd and 3rd point of XXXX"(6 points raised in class)

There are group discussions every class. The group is randomly assigned and if your group is active(like mine), you get interesting insights from your peers.

The TA is very nice, he speaks cantonese, mandarin and of course,English fluently .
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading: 17%Attendance +30% 1st mid + 23% 2nd mid+ 30% 3rd mid.

I think the grading is good. Mean about B.The materials absolutely helps you get better grades in the exam as some examples will be asked.

The midterms includes MC/short Q/long Q.
1st midterm: mean 19.9/25
2nd midterm: mean 16.9/20
3rd mid not released. ???/20(maybe about 15 or 16)


Me:
1st:22,
2nd:18
3rd: 16.5(I asked for it)
Attendance:100%
Overall:A-
reviews.comment_workload:
3 midterms, not cumulative. reading materials & attendance.
If you go to the lecture, you get the attendance, participation not considered.
Quite light wrkld comparing to other huma courses.
The worload depends on you. For me, I didn't read the materials, but paid full attention during class, it's still ok for me to get an A range.

reviews.author: Cynthia Hui
reviews.comment_content: basically what you expect from a philosophy course; the material overlaps with yuma 1000b this term actually, but here its more detail oriented while huma1000b has a more macro view
reviews.comment_teaching: the class is divided into groups of around 6 people, and the prof alloacted a lot of discussion time so don't take the course if you're not the type of person who likes to think and chip in
reviews.comment_grading: 17% attendance score (one for each lesson, you have one quota to miss the class), 3 quizzes, non accumulative
reviews.comment_workload: homework mainly revolves around reading; it's  a decent amount of work but it might be quite hard to understand and think over if your english proficiency is bad or if you're not interested in philosophy at all

reviews.title: 西哲入門

reviews.author: Heng
reviews.title: 正，好COURSE
reviews.comment_content:
內容不深,PPT非常清晰,而且主要用於理解readings和主題. 另外上堂不少互動,對哲學的討論,理解等等的意見交流,非常有趣

有提及孟子的孺子將入於井,柏拉圖的gyges' ring,Hobbes的leviathan,buber I and Thou....總之很多不同的哲學家的理論和思想.
而最後一個課題是比較近代的Peter Singer,主將動物權利,以及leopold的land ethics,講及人與土地的關係等等,先有經典著作,再有現代哲學與生活的關係等等,若對哲學問題有興趣的話,會很喜歡這科.
reviews.comment_teaching: 教學主要是讀ppt,之後分組討論,不算十分吸引,但作為對教學內容的理解有很好幫助
reviews.comment_grading:
grading:
17% attendance(1% per class)
54% quiz(27% per quiz)
29% final
對於不愛上堂的同學來說是一大挑戰,遲到15分鐘就不能點名.但同時好的地方是點名只是單純在ta手上的點名字tick名,沒有任何要求,不同上堂參與之類.
另外quiz個人覺得不太難,平均分大約是21-22分(out of 27),我2次均只讀ppt和少量readings即過mean.
quiz和final的考試模式非常接近,有mc,有填充,有true of false,最後有short essay,而short essay的套路不難捉摸.其他的話如果非常熟悉ppt的內容,大概滿分能取23-24左右,餘下數分的就會是readings的分數,readings相關的題目,在之後的quiz跟final會愈來愈多.
最後final的成績沒有公布,我在2次都僅高mean1-2分情況下,final溫了一半的readings,b+. 有朋友跟我一樣2次都高mean1-2分,但最後c+,可能final影響很大.
reviews.comment_workload:
不用essay,不用上堂參與,只考3次試和上堂,比起很多course而言,功課量算非常輕鬆.
但readings非常具挑戰性.主要是古英語的readings,而且是外語再翻為英語的篇章,非常難讀. 量的話算適中,每堂1x pages,而且最主要的部分,professor會在堂上的ppt讀一次給同學,而且再加以他個人的理解及解釋文章大意,即使不認真讀readings都可跟上進度.

reviews.author: CKL
reviews.comment_content: At the beginning of the course, it mainly focuses on virtue ethics, utilitarianism and deontology. After that, the course includes some contemporary issues, such as punishment, animal rights, world hunger and land ethic, which are required to apply the 3 theories learnt.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think the teaching style is quite good. In each lecture, the instructor explains the theories in the first half of the lesson. In another half, students are discussing in groups about some questions raised by the instructor. He and the TA join different groups to discuss, which make us know the topic better. The instructor is very friendly, which makes the lessons relaxing.
reviews.comment_grading:
This is a good-graded course if you are willing to spend time on the readings.

The grade of the course is based on 17% of attendance (1% per lesson), 27% of each quiz (there are 2 quizzes), and 29% of the final exam.

Below are some statistics:
1st quiz: mean ~ 21/27
2nd quiz: mean ~ 21/27

I scored 21 and 23 in 1st and 2nd quiz, just slightly above mean. As the score of final exam is not announced, I do not know whether I have done well. However, I think the instructor is willing to give good grades, as I eventually got an A-.
reviews.comment_workload: I think the workload depends on how hard-working you are. If you do not expect too much on grades, then just finishing about 30 pages of powerpoint slides per week is a quite low workload, as there are no homework, only lecture attendance, 2 quizzes and final exam. However, if you want to score a bit above mean, you have to do the readings assigned. There will be a reading with about 6-pages long per lesson, reading all of them will be a tough task, especially for the readings that are written in ancient-style english.
